049895cd57189f883fabf12ce89157be.title: Understanding the NBA Trade Deadline Leverage Game

a1f311636cd29c6069441cb6b5959f13.title: Understanding the NBA Trade Deadline Leverage Game

paragraphs.text: The promise of change can be invigorating. We Trade Machine Picassos spend countless hours debating on Twitter and Reddit about transaction rumors because we want to remix the song we’re hearing. But trades aren’t made to satisfy our desire for upheaval. Roster turnover usually occurs steadily rather than abruptly, and a superstar’s tenure on a team is difficult to end. Even if Sunday’s DeMarcus Cousins–to-the-Pelicans trade seemed sudden, it was clearly the product of years of internal debate among the Kings leadership, and was executed with an eye toward the future. The Kings decided they did not want to pay the approximately $200 million Cousins would make in a contract extension.
paragraphs.name: a5fc

paragraphs.name: ea63
paragraphs.text: If I’m Magic Johnson, I’m calling the Bulls and offering any combination of players (outside of Brandon Ingram) in exchange for Jimmy Butler. Butler is the kind of player who needs a change of scenery and would be easy to build around.

virtuals.subtitle: Why else would they have that many consecutive 50 win seasons and consecutive playoff appearances. Not a single franchise in the league can…

paragraphs.name: ee24
paragraphs.text: There is ONLY ONE team in the league who absolutely and consistently cares about winning it all: The Spurs.
Why else would they have that many consecutive 50 win seasons and consecutive playoff appearances. Not a single franchise in the league can claim this dedication to winning over anything else.
